string-array.name: strings_learn_getting_started_toptext
string-array.item: Pinyin sounds are composed of an \"initial\" and a \"final.\" Most finals are full pinyin sounds in themselves such as the most basic final, \"a.\" The \"a\" final is pronounced like the \"a\" in the English word \"father.\"
The \"b,\" \"p,\" \"m,\" and \"f\" initials are pronounced like their English counterparts.

string-array.name: strings_learn_getting_started_bottomtext
string-array.item: Tap the pinyin to hear how it is pronounced.
Note that some initial-final combinations do not exist in Mandarin.

string-array.name: learn_more_simple_sounds_toptext
string-array.item: The \"d\", \"t\", \"n\" and \"l\" initials are pronounced as they would be in English.

string-array.name: learn_adding_o_finals_toptext
string-array.item: The Mandarin \"o\" final by itself only combines with the \"b\", \"p\", \"m\" and \"f\" initials.
The \"o\" in the \"ong\" final is very similar to the English \"oh\" sound. That is, \"long\" is pronounced \"l-oh-ng\", not \"l-ah-ng\".
The \"ou\" final is very similar to the English \"oh\" sound, except one\'s lips start to round towards the end. This creates a slightly more exaggerated \"oo\" sound at the end.

string-array.name: learn_adding_o_finals_bottomtext
string-array.item: While not completely foreign, this sound is very different from any sound in English.
The \"ong\" final is not a valid pinyin sound unless combined with an initial. It also does not combine with the \"b\", \"p\", \"m\" and \"f\" initials.
This final combines with all of the initials we\'ve covered so far except for the \"o\" final.
